questions.text: In retaliation for the 1599 Acoma Revolt, Governor Juan de Oñate ordered

answers.text: the complete destruction of Acoma Pueblo, including its buildings and people.
the imprisonment of a few key leaders of the revolt.
the mutilation of all Acoma men over the age of twenty-five.
that no actions be taken for fear of further infuriating Pueblo peoples.

questions.text: During the final push for New Mexico's statehood, officials in the U.S. Senate proposed a measure called jointure that would have

answers.text: created a joint state out of New Mexico, Arizona, and Oklahoma territories.
combined New Mexico and Arizona into one large state called 'Montezuma.'
divided New Mexico into two smaller states.
prevented New Mexico's statehood for another decade.

questions.text: Hispano residents of New Mexico territory began to refer to themselves as 'Spanish Americans' in the late nineteenth century in order to

answers.text: emphasize their white, Spanish ancestry and disassociate themselves with Mexican or indigenous heritage to appear more acceptable for statehood.
qualify for land grants offered under the Homestead Act of 1862.
prevent the continued influx of Anglo Americans from the Eastern United States.
reestablish ties with the Spanish government that had once ruled the area.

questions.text: In the early 1940s, directors of the Manhattan Project chose to locate their top-secret nuclear weapons program to ________, New Mexico due to its remote location and prior experience in the area.

answers.text: Albuquerque
Los Alamos
Ruidoso
Alamogordo

questions.text: __________ and __________ were two of the centers of Ancestral Puebloan (formerly Anasazi) culture during the period between 700 and 1200 CE.

answers.text: Casas Grandes; Pecos Pueblo
Third Mesa; Chaco Canyon
Chaco Canyon; Mesa Verde
Ohkay Owingeh; Kewa

questions.text: Following the U.S.-Mexico War, the process of surveying the new border between the United States and Mexico was complicated because

answers.text: the Disturnell Map used by negotiators of the Treaty of Guadalupe Hidalgo was inaccurate and in 1849 the Rio Grande changed its course.
border commissioners routinely became ill in the desert heat and were unable to complete their assignments.
the Treaty of Guadalupe Hidalgo was never ratified.
armed bandits and nomadic natives prevented the boundary commission from completing its task.
a criminal network comprised of petty thieves and bandits near Santa Fe.
a social club for former politicians.
a guild of Santa Fe jewelers.
a thinly veiled political machine directed by Thomas B. Catron.

questions.text: The Navajo Long Walk was planned by ___________ and orchestrated by _________.

answers.text: Juan de Oñate; Antonio de Zaldivar
Sheriff Pat Garrett; Billy the Kid
James Henry Carleton; Christopher 'Kit' Carson
Governor Clyde Tingley; Senator Dennis Chávez

questions.text: The Spanish-colonial 'casta' system was a means of

answers.text: casting blame against those who had committed a crime.
identifying everyone in society based on their degree of limpieza de sangre, or the purity of their blood.
defining the various branches of the colonial government.
differentiating between people who worked for governors, the Church, and encomenderos.

questions.text: The name 'New Mexico' (Nuevo México) originated with the earliest Spanish explorers of the region, including members of the Coronado expedition, because they hoped to find

answers.text: gold and riches comparable to those of the great Aztec Empire, the first Mexico.
thousands of hostile indigenous peoples whom they would have to subjugate.
another great city like Tenochtitlan that had been constructed on a lake.
small, sedentary societies that could be integrated into the Spanish Empire.
